description.text:
This is a support for the Elektor Flashboard microcontroller system (http://www.elektor.com/products/kits-modules/kits/070125-71-usb-flash-board.271292.lynkx). The holes in the support correspond to the holes of a BoeBot chassis, which is slightly less wide than the controllerboard. The controllerboard can be mounted on the support with 4 small M3 bolts. For attaching it to the BoeBot chassis you'll need an extra 3 M3 bolts and nuts.
The Sketchup file is included, so the support can be adapted to other microcontroller systems.
Print. Attach it to the BoeBot chassis and mount the controllerboard on top.
with this housing you can attach a standard servo to a baseplate. The servo slides in, and the baseplate keeps it in place. You can use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28576 as baseplate.
Print. Slide the servo in, and attach to a baseplate.

I've seen this type of scroll saw table insert in a lot of scroll saws, but had difficulty finding a replacement for mine. This design is perhaps a little smaller than I would like (by 1/2mm overall radius, and perhaps 1/4mm to short), but I'm pretty pleased with it and a lot closer to proper dimensions than the piece of Masonite I had cut a replacement out of before.
You'll want to rotate this so that it prints flat on your printer.

comments.text: I got a big crack in mine somehow. Thanks for designing this!
comments.author: RickParty

description.text:
Built with Tinkercad.  
This is a model for holding 90 mm by 103.9 mm hex tiles for board games, typically Settlers of Catan and Eclipse.  It uses six 1.5 mm by 3 mm magnets.

The model works well printed out by a Replicator 2 (2 shells, 0.30mm thickness, 90 mm/s speed, lowest fill possible). Each hex requires six 1.5 mm by 3.0 mm magnets. Force in with a pair of pliers, or glue in if too loose.
Alternate magnet poles orientation: no side should have the same outwards polarity as its neighbours.

title: Steampunk/Art Deco Dual Light Switch Plate

description.text: I had originally made a simple version of this with Glow in the dark filament. It is designed to snap onto the switches, after you remove original plate. No screws required. I did this as I have a lot of static electricity in my home during winter months, no metal screws dramatically reduced the zapping.

author: intrepid

description.text:
A printed bearing that will fit the 1kg filament spools from repraper.com I have made two versions:
  • for a 16mm shaft
  • for a 10mm shaft
    • ADDED:
  • for a 8mm shaft
    • If you need a bearing with a specific shaft diameter, just ask. if printed correctly these bearings will roll quite nicely and reduce friction between spool and shaft.

Needs to be printed with no greater that 0.2mm Z resolution to get the ball bearings spherical. I printed mine with 0.175mm and 25% infill. The ball bearings are 5mm diameter and have 0.25mm clearance to the races.  
They must be printed with some support to ensure that the ball bearings don't touch the inner and outer races. Use minimal support to ease the cleanup. I printed mine with only medium and 80deg support (kisslicer setting)  
Make sure to break all the ball bearings apart and get all the support out from inside the bearing. Use a scalpel to cut the "tips" of the ball bearings where necessary.  
I spent about 10-12min cleanup pr. bearing

description.text:
V1 is the model in the pictures and v2 uses less plastic. I printed the one pictured but, I haven't printed v2 yet. They both have built in strain reliefs that can be secured using small zip ties.  
These are a work in progress. If you need any small modifications to the design, let me know and I will see what I can do. I will be making one similar to this for Printrbots ExtrudrBoard. I plan to eventually add a top with a fan mount.  
Update: I added version 1.1 which has holes to be mounted on Printrbot Simples platform. Version 2.2 is the same but uses less plastic to print. I also added a new version with longer releifs.
The pictured version of V1 was printed in ABS with 15% infill, .3 layer height, 235 degrees C hotend temp, 110 degrees C bed temp and it printed well the first time.

comments.text: Are you referring to the vertical walls in the corners. I could either remove the corners or place a hole. Which do you prefer?

comments.text: Very nice.  Have you considered adding a hole next to the mounting screw locations for a zip tie to be fed through?  This would allow you to strap it to the side of the Simple.

author: MadEdd

description.text: Sonar mount for arrow shaft
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/09TNRA54W56

The original design was great but the size was a little too large for some tastes.
These were cleaned up in netfab, scaled 65% (x and y) and the hanger was adjusted back to the original size.  Based on the STL since I don't have solid works.
These printed fine on my ToM at this size with 100% fill and zero shells.
Print and hang on earrings.
The Plasma Gun from Howard Tayler's Schlock Mercenary, a web comic that has published daily for over ten years now.  I will try to post the figure if I get permission.

title: RepRap Mendel to Perusa Upgrade! Uses Rotary Bearings, not Linear

description.text: Have a Mendle fame? Want to reduce the belt length and reduce chatter? The only reason you are holding onto it is because you don't have linear bearings? Well, look no further, for I was in your shoes! This is it! The thing you are looking for! I printed it off on my old frame and upgraded it to this state.

author: Chusky

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner. Still having trouble getting anything but "cones" out of my scans. It was interesting to note that when scanned on "Medium" during the preview scan, it was only picking up the yellow portions. Then, as it flipped on the second laser, the portions did not line up and were mirrored. The conical shape was evident even during the preview scan, and the result is what you see.

comments.text: Not everyday I see WayneState people online in these parts. Are you still in the city? I've got a studio downtown and we just picked up a makerbot rep2, any interest in collaboration?
comments.author: magic6435

comments.text: I actually work for Wayne State in the College of Engineering. I'm the IT guy trying to get better scans out of the Replicator for our Biomedical Engineering Undergraduate research group. It seems to pretty fickle. One day I can get decent scans, another day, I get cones and blobs.
comments.author: magic6435

comments.text: It's not just that object. I've tried various places for the Replicator, and recalibrating. I'm getting slightly better results currently, but it's not consistent, at all.
comments.author: Lurgid

comments.text: It would be interesting to see what the scan looked like during the scan.  However, a few things - dark, shiny objects are going to be hard to scan, it's best to have the digitizer pointed at a dark wall and not a white piece of cardboard/paper, also the overhead lights being in view of the camera might be a problem as well.  You may also need to re-align the lasers and re-calibrate.
comments.author: tbuser

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

comments.text: What did it look like before the scanner had it's way with it?

remixed_from.author: obijuan
remixed_from.title: ArduSnake: Arduino Modular Snake Robots Library

description.text:
The PrintBot Crab is an educational robot that can walk as an hexapod and can grab objects with its pincers.
You can see the robot in action at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bb_dW-XyTIc
This modular robot has been designed to attach other components such as servos, LEDs, push buttons, a buzzer, and other sensors included in the product "Mi primer kit de robotica" ("My first robotics kit") distributed by bq.

• 1xBattery_holder
  • 1xCangrejo_body
  • 1xCangrejo_central_legs
  • 1xCangrejo_central_servo_support
  • 1xCangrejo_eyes
  • 1xCangrejo_pincers_LEFT
  • 1xCangrejo_pincers_RIGHT
  • 1xCangrejo_shell
  • 2xCangrejo_axes_link
  • 2xCangrejo_back_leg
  • 2xCangrejo_front_leg

    Electronic Components:

  • 1 x Freaduino UNO (Arduino UNO derivative)
  • 3 x Miniservos (ES08A or similar)
  • 1 x 8 AAA battery holder

    Optional Electronic Components:

  • 1 x Bluetooth module

    Hardware:

  • 8 x AAA batteries
  • 2 x M3x40 screw
  • 2 x M3x35 screw
  • 3 x M3x16 screw
  • 8 x M3x12 screw
  • 15 x M3 nut
  • 4 x Little rubber bands
  • 6 x Rubber ferrule (10mm diameter)

    Build Instructions

    See the attached pdf (in Spanish). Pictures are clear enough to follow the steps even if you do not understand Spanish.

    Example code

    Attached you will find the Arduino programs. The principal program use the Oscilator librarie based on Ardusnake made by obijuan
    [see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21401]

    Author

    Ana de Prado Navarrete

    Disclaimer

    This thing and all other published material cannot be considered as a final product of bq and bq takes no responsibility of its use.
    It must be considered as an experimental and early released product developed by the Innovation and Robotics Department staff with the intention to share it and test it as soon as possible within the community.
    Final releases will be published on http://diwo.bq.com & http://diwo.bq.com/montaje-del-printbot-crab/
